Q14: The shared video at the end was unnecessary. I'm fond of the overall conversation flow but personally I wouldn't use a bot like this if it only works for one particular class. If I could manage all of my assigned coursework easily enough for a bot like GritBot to be able to plug into it, I'd probably just set up cron reminders for myself and skip the whole "bot interaction" thing. That being said, I'm sure a lot of other people would appreciate a bot like this working for them.
Q15: This seems a bit ambitious for a 6-week chatbot project. I'd also deem it somewhat unnecessary - I can search Google Scholar myself for 10 to 20 papers faster than the one paper that GritBot found and the user agreed to open. Also, displaying the whole abstract in a chat interface is a bit overboard. I would just link the user to the 10 top results and leave it at that. Conversations should be short and to-the-point.
Q16: Why did you score a 9/10 if the feedback said "I have given you 10/10 on your assignment"? Nice move to allow GritBot to generate posts to Friday Reflections - it's a good way to help get those pesky participation points out of the way. A bit ambitious to poke into the Piazza API and grab feedback and specific threads, though.
Q17: I'm pretty much fine with this one.
Q18: I think GritBot's conversations are a bit wordy. I'm not inclined to read large chunks of info in an instant chat format, regardless of content. I might just not be a good use case for a system like GritBot since I do my own time and effort management.

Q14: Seemed quite long for a robot. Especially the part where it explains the grading info for the survey. Can you imagine having to learn about how the grading works every week for the past 7 weeks? That's gotta be annoying.
Q15: Yikes! This one is a terrible idea! Having to get 10 messages every time you're interested in something stinks. And then getting the abstract in individual messages like that? Why would anyone think that would be helpful? If nothing else, it's just a glorified Let Me Google That For You bot. Anyone could find information faster just by googling it themselves rather than answering 1 - 10 a bunch of times.
Q16: Besides the obvious of saying they scored 9 out of 10 and then later the mentor saying they were given 10/10, I liked the robot in this conversation. A little less useful if the instructor isn't one to leave comments but perfect here.
Q17: lol, I liked that Carlos worked at a level 3 effort on this class. ;P
Q18: Make the survey shorter next time. After watching all the videos and going back and forth between this page and the demos I eventually was logged out of the survey group and had to retake your whole thing!

Q14: Some of the necessary seems superfluous for week 7. For example, the messages "The fastest you provide feedback to your peers, the better..." and "Thus if you provide all peer reviews..." and "In contrast..." are long and probably already known by the user by Week 7. It makes the bot feel 'spammy'. Otherwise, I love the concept, especially the scheduling.
Q15: "Pick a topic" should accept the topics themselves, not just the 1-10 index.  Also sending the top 10 articles as 10 separate messages (and no links until you get to the end of the workflow? -- takes too long) seems very spammy. Maybe top 3 at most would be interesting. Also, if this is use case is done weekly, how often does the content change? E.g, there are not new 'intelligent tutoring systems' articles in google scholar every week, so this content becomes less useful week after week?

Q14: Cool video mockup! I particularly like the help with planning the week. One suggestion is to remove the "Should I remind you?" and just assume they want to be reminded. Less is more!
Q15: My feedback here is similar to the last one. Instead of asking "Do you want some articles" and "Which topic?" just spit out some recomendations, maybe 2 articles for the top 3 interests. You really want to slim down these interactions or the bot will be too cumbersome to use.

Q18: In general, just try to achieve the goal of any given interaction with a little back-and-forth as possible. Personally, I'm not a fan of reading a lot text nor writing a lot of text. Also, can you choose a tech stack that is platform-independent? Maybe a web app or some boilerplate chat app that lets you implement the AI? I would definitely like the ability to use the bot on desktop as well as mobile. Overall, best mockups I've seen so far, good work! Please check out mine if you've get chance https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1xn81WCWKxe-fCwP8JucB3jQTrMRyXnaquMQLrA0rPXc/edit?usp=sharing
